Keywords n-Octane VMgO preparation Acidity Octenes Styrene 1 Introduction The merits of the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of the inexpensive alkanes to produce the synthetically more valuable products, such as olefins and aromatics, represents a driving force that motivates the research for developing active and selective catalysts for this purpose. Since the report by Kung and co-workers [1], the usage of VMgO catalysts in attempts to convert short-chain alkanes into the corresponding value-added products such as olefins and dienes was a matter of investigation [2–6]. In fact, they are among the most active and selective catalysts in the oxidative dehydrogenation of short-chain alkanes. Because of its low tendency to form oxygenates and cracking products [1,5,7,8], the VMgO system was considered as a good candidate for the oxidative dehydrogenation of long-chain alkanes such as n-octane. Thus, we employed these catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-octane to produce the corresponding linear octenes and C8 aromatics [9,10]. The challenge in the mixed oxide catalysts, in general, is the preparation of a solid with a high degree of dispersion [11–13]. In the VMgO system, magnesium oxide (basic) is likely to interact intensively with vanadium (acidic), which will eventually lead to a good dispersion of vanadium on the support and presumably a good ODH performance. An interesting feature related to this was that incorporation of vanadium into MgO inhibits the formation of V2O5 [6,14]. This oxide, because of its exposed VO bond, is believed to enhance the formation of oxygenates and total combustion products [1,4,6]. Supports, in general, play an important role in determining the catalyst's properties and hence the catalytic performance [2,4]. Vanadia-based catalysts are believed to be affected by the nature of the metal oxide used as support [2,4,8,15–17]. Magnesium oxide is one of the most important supports used in catalyst preparation. In MgO, the morphological and chemical properties, such as surface area, particle shapes, concentration of edges and corners, and degree of surface hydroxylation were found to be dependent on the method of preparation [18–20]. By analogy, MgO interaction with vanadium during the preparation of VMgO catalysts is likely to be influenced by these properties, and hence lead to the formation of VMgO catalysts with different properties and consequently different catalytic performance. In support of this, it was reported that vanadium supported on MgO with different crystallite sizes showed different catalytic performance during the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane [21]. It should be added that the degree of interaction between vanadium and magnesium oxide is believed to be one of the important factors that determine the properties and the catalytic performance of VMgO catalysts [3,22]. We recently reported on the oxidative activation of n-octane over cobalt-substituted ceria and vanadium-supported hydroxyapatite catalysts [23,24]. In contrast, the characteristic feature of the VMgO catalysts, that is their poor tendency to form oxygenates, cracking and isomerization products, makes them good catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of a long-chain alkane, such as n-octane, for the production of linear octenes and C8 aromatics; in this oxygen-containing environment, n-octane would be susceptible to combustion and cracking. This justifies further investigation of the VMgO system for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-octane, especially since the world production of medium chain length paraffins (C7–C10 linear alkanes) exceeds 1Mt p.a. Influencing the properties and catalytic performance of VMgO catalysts has been attempted by changing the method of preparation [7,13,25–27], varying the vanadium loadings [1,7,9,28,29], and varying the calcination temperatures and time [28–30]. In this study, we investigated the effects of using different MgO precursors (oxalate and hydroxide) and different precursor treatments on the properties and catalytic performance of the resultant VMgO catalysts. These synthesized catalysts were tested for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-octane to produce linear octenes and C8 aromatics. 2 Experimental All the catalysts were prepared at a nominal concentration of 15% for V2O5 (to the total of the combined V2O5 and MgO). This is because a catalyst with this concentration has shown the better performance during the activation of n-octane [9]. 2.1 Catalysts synthesis Magnesium oxalate was prepared by a procedure similar to that reported in [9]. Thus, an aqueous solution of magnesium acetate (40g in 700ml) was heated to 50°C. A hot aqueous solution of oxalic acid, which contained the stoichiometric amount needed to form MgC2O4 (25g in 700ml), was also heated to 50°C and added to the acetate solution. The resultant mixture was heated and magnetically stirred for half an hour. The resultant solid (magnesium oxalate) was filtered off using a Buchner funnel. The precipitate so-obtained was washed thoroughly with cold and hot water and placed overnight in an oven operated at 110°C. MgO was obtained by heating the magnesium oxalate under vacuum at 600°C for 6h and was designated MgO(1). In another approach, 15g of a commercial MgO was placed in a 2000ml round-bottomed flask that contained 1000ml of water. This mixture was refluxed (with magnetic stirring) for 8h. Using a Buchner funnel, the precipitate (magnesium hydroxide) was collected and placed overnight in an oven operated at 110°C. The resultant Mg(OH)2 was heated under vacuum at 600°C for 6h and the magnesium oxide so-obtained was designated MgO(2). Another part of the above prepared Mg(OH)2 was heated in a furnace at 600°C for 6h and the resultant magnesium oxide was designated MgO(3). The prepared magnesium oxides MgO(1), MgO(2), and MgO(3) were used to synthesized three VMgO catalysts, viz., VMgO(1), VMgO(2), and VMgO(3), respectively. The three catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method using the procedure that was outlined in [9]. Thus, the above prepared magnesium oxides were impregnated with a clear hot aqueous solution of NH4VO3 (greenish yellow in colour) that contained the amount of vanadium needed to give a nominal concentration of 15% for the V2O5 to the total weight of both V2O5 and MgO. As an example, for the catalyst VMgO(2), 2.3012g of ammonium metavanadate was dissolved in 800ml of water and heated at 60°C till the vanadate was completely dissolved. The hot solution was then added to MgO (10.1045g) and the resultant mixture was heated, while magnetically stirred, till a paste was formed. The resultant paste was then placed in an oven and left overnight at 110°C. This catalyst was ground, thoroughly mixed, and calcined at 550°C for 5h. Temperature ramping during the calcination was about 1.5°/min. The same procedure was followed for the synthesis of VMgO(1) and VMgO(3) using MgO(1) and MgO(3), respectively. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The elemental composition of the catalysts was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) using an Optima 5300 DV PerkinElmer Optical Emission Spectrometer. For the surface area measurements, catalysts samples were first degassed in a stream of nitrogen at 473K for 24h. The BET surface areas were then measured by nitrogen adsorption isotherms at 77K using the standard multipoint method on a Micromeritics Gemini instrument. The pore volumes were also determined on this Micromeritics Gemini instrument. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Philips PW1050 Diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator and operated at 40kV and 40mA. The source of radiation was Co Kα and all data were captured by a Sietronics 122D automated microprocessor. The average crystallite size was calculated by the Scherrer equation using the diffraction line at 2θ =50°. The vanadium magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (51V MAS NMR) spectra were recorded at 600MHz on a Bruker Avance III 600 NMR Spectrometer fitted with a Bruker Solid State Probe. A cylindrical zirconia rotor, which contained the packed catalyst sample, was rotated at a speed of 12kHz during the data acquisition. A pulse length of 2.5μs and a pulse delay of 1s were used. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained using a LEO 1450 Scanning Electron Microscope. Samples for these SEM images were coated with gold using a Polaron SC Sputter Coater. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was carried out using a Jeol JSM 6100 Scanning Electron Microscope equipped with a Bruker EDX Detector. Samples for the EDX were coated with carbon in a Jeol JEE-4C Vacuum Evaporator. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were performed on a Micromeritics 2900 AutoChem II Chemisorption Analyzer. Prior to the reduction, the catalyst (about 0.05g) was pretreated by being heated under a stream of argon (30ml/min) at 400°C for 30min and then cooled down to 80°C under the same stream of argon. 5% H2 in argon was then used as a reducing agent at a flow rate of 50ml/min. Under these reducing conditions, the temperature was ramped up to 950°C at a rate of 10°/min. To identify the resultant phases after reduction, powder XRD was carried out on the catalyst samples after the TPR experiments. NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were carried out using a Micromeritics 2900 AutoChem II Chemisorption Analyzer. To clean the catalyst's surface, about 0.02g of the catalyst was first flushed at 350°C with helium flowing at 20ml/min for 30min and the temperature was thereafter brought down to 80°C. A 4.1% ammonia in helium mixture was then passed (20ml/min) over the catalyst for 30min. The system was flushed with helium (30ml/min) for 30min to remove the excess ammonia. The adsorbed ammonia was then stripped off by the same stream of helium (30ml/min) and a temperature ramp of up to 900°C (at 10°/min), and the desorption profiles were recorded. 2.3 Catalytic testing The catalytic testing was carried out in a fixed bed continuous flow reactor that operated in a down flow mode. The reactor tube was stainless steel with an internal diameter of 10mm and a length of 220mm. The catalyst volume was 1ml (ca. 0.45g) and the catalyst pellets’ sizes were between 600 and 1000μm. The catalyst was placed between two layers of glass wool and the rest of the reactor tube was packed with carborandum. An electrically heated block was used to heat the reactor tube. The temperature of the catalyst bed was monitored with a coaxially centred thermocouple that was placed in the middle of the catalyst's bed. A LabAlliance Series II HPLC pump was used to deliver the n-octane to the reactor system. The flow rates of the oxidant (air) and the make-up gas (nitrogen) were controlled by ABB rotameters. The liquid products and the unreacted n-octane were collected in a cylindrical stainless steel vessel cooled to about 2°C. A Ritter Drum-Type Gas Metre was used to measure the total volume of the gas that came out of the reactor. The catalytic tests were carried out at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 8000h−1 (total flow rate of 134ml/min). The flow rates of n-octane, air, and nitrogen were 12, 72, and 50ml/min, respectively. This gives an n-octane to oxygen molar ratio of 0.8. The products of the catalytic testing were analyzed by a Perkin-Elmer Clarus 500 Gas Chromatograph equipped with both an FID and a TCD. The TCD was used for the quantification of carbon oxides and the FID for the rest of the components. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Textural properties As shown in Table 1 , the surface areas and crystallite sizes of the catalysts are different, which indicates that changing the MgO precursor and precursor's treatment induces changes in the textural properties of the resultant VMgO catalysts. Also, the porosity is relatively higher on the catalysts VMgO(1) and VMgO(2) (Table 1), which indicates a positive effect on the porosity as a result of treating MgO precursors under vacuum. A difference in the crystallite size of VMgO(1) on one hand and crystallite sizes of VMgO(2) and VMgO(3) on the other is also observed (Table 1), which reflects the effect of MgO precursors on the resultant catalysts, as MgO for VMgO(1) was obtained from MgC2O4 and for VMgO(2) and VMgO(3) it was obtained from Mg(OH)2. Also, a noticeable feature was that vanadium concentration on the catalyst's surface was likely highest on VMgO(2) and lowest on VMgO(1). 3.1.2 Powder X-ray diffraction The diffractograms of the calcined catalysts, Fig. 1 , indicate the formation of two crystalline phases in each catalyst, viz., magnesium oxide and magnesium orthovanadate. Each of the three catalysts shows diffraction lines corresponding to d spacings of 2.11Å (2θ =50.2°) and 2.45Å (2θ =43°), which are attributable to magnesium oxide and magnesium orthovanadate, respectively [1,31]. The manifestation of the orthovanadate, however, was different in the three catalysts. Thus, VMgO(2), VMgO(3), and VMgO(1) showed one (2θ =43°), two (2θ =41 and 43°), and four (2θ =34, 41, 42, and 69°) lines attributable to this phase, respectively [1,31]. In short, the presence of magnesium orthovanadate is well-manifested in VMgO(1) (four diffraction lines) and poorly shown in VMgO(2) (one line); the two catalysts differ in the precursors that were used in the synthesis of MgO. The poor manifestation of the orthovanadate phase on the catalyst VMgO(2) may indicate good vanadium dispersion, as poor dispersion will lead to association and thereby accelerating the formation of the orthovanadate. It should be added here that it is believed that in VMgO catalysts prepared by the impregnation method, vanadate adsorbs on the surface of MgO, and that for Mg3V2O8 to be formed, vanadium ions have to migrate inside the MgO support [13,22]. As a consequence, the formation of Mg3V2O8 will probably be accompanied by a low vanadium concentration on the catalyst's surface; this is indeed in a good agreement with our XRD data and the EDX results. To get more insights about the chemical transformations during the impregnation and calcination steps, powder XRD was performed on the uncalcined catalysts (Fig. 2 ). Worth mentioning here is that it was believed that some properties of the VMgO catalysts were affected by the chemical modifications that took place during the impregnation step [7,22]. Before calcinations, as shown in Fig. 2, the diffractograms indicate the formation of both magnesium pyrovanadate and orthovanadate in all the catalysts. For VMgO(1), the existence of magnesium pyrovanadate before calcination was indicated by the lines at 2θ equal to 27 and 33° (d spacings of 3.86 and 3.17Å), while for VMgO(2) and VMgO(3), the existence of this phase was indicated by the lines at 2θ equal to 22 and 27° (d spacings of 4.78 and 3.85Å) [31,32,29]. This indicates that magnesium pyrovanadate in VMgO(1) exhibits at least one different lattice plane (crystal face) than those observed for VMgO(2) and VMgO(3); the support for the former, VMgO(1), was prepared by using different precursor (magnesium oxalate instead of hydroxide). The same observation (exhibiting different planes) was valid for magnesium orthovanadate in the three catalysts before calcination, as the diffractogram of the uncalcined VMgO(1) (Fig. 2a) showed peaks assignable to this phase at 2θ equal 34.4 and 52° (d spacings of 3.03 and 2.04Å); these additional two peaks were not shown by the diffractograms of the uncalcined VMgO(2) and VMgO(3) catalysts. Also, an interesting feature in the diffractograms of the uncalcined catalysts was that VMgO(2) and VMgO(3), unlike VMgO(1), showed a peak at 2θ equal 50° (d spacing of 2.11Å), which is assignable to MgO. So, it may be suggested that the phasic composition of the VMgO catalysts was affected more by the precursor used to prepare MgO, rather than the precursor treatment. 3.1.3 51V magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) 51V NMR spectroscopy can provide valuable information about the coordination environment around the vanadium atoms. The NMR spectrum of each catalyst is composed of one signal (Fig. 3 ), which suggests that there is one type of coordination symmetry around the vanadium atoms in all the catalysts. The resonance at −550ppm indicates the existence of tetrahedral vanadium species (VO4) in an environment similar to that of orthovanadate [33–35]. The slight differences in the values of these resonance lines, however, indicate different degrees of distortion in the VO4 species on the three catalysts. Magnesium pyrovanadate is characterized by two coordination sites around vanadium atoms [33–35], which will presumably give two resonance lines. According to the assignments in [33,34], the absence of any signal in the range −620 to −650ppm indicates the absence of magnesium pyrovanadate. This is in a good agreement with the results of the XRD (Section 3.1.2), where no evidence for the formation of the magnesium pyrovanadate phase was found. Moreover, no line attributable to environments other than the tetrahedral coordination was detected, which indicates that neither V2O5 (square pyramidal) nor MgV2O6 (distorted octahedral environment) was formed. 3.1.4 Scanning electron microscopy The SEM images of VMgO(1) and VMgO(2), Fig. 4a and b, respectively, reveal rough surfaces that clearly show folded platelets structures. The support (MgO) for these two catalysts was obtained by treating the precursors (MgC2O4 and Mg(OH)2) under vacuum. An obvious feature in the micrograph of VMgO(1) is the presence of an aggregate-like structure (on the right-hand side of the micrograph), which indicates that vanadium species (probably in the orthovanadate phase) show some sort of agglomeration. In the micrograph of VMgO(3), Fig. 4c, the roughness of the surface, as well as the platelets structure, were not clearly shown, as was the case for the VMgO(1) and VMgO(2) catalysts; the support's precursor for this catalyst was treated under static air in a furnace (not under vacuum). However, the aggregate-like structure can be seen as bright particles that are randomly scattered over the catalyst's surface (Fig. 4c). To sum up, the SEM images indicate that the surface morphology was different over the three catalysts, and that the surface morphology was more affected by the precursors’ treatment, rather than the chemical differences of these precursors. 3.1.5 Temperature-programmed reduction H2-TPR experiments were carried out to investigate the reducibility of the catalysts. For each catalyst, the TPR profile shows one reduction peak (Fig. 5 ), indicating that vanadium atoms exist in one environment; in a good agreement with the XRD and NMR results. As shown in Table 2 , the maximum temperature for reduction was almost the same for the catalysts VMgO(1) and VMgO(3); however, for the catalyst VMgO(2) it was slightly higher (by about 23°C), indicating a relatively lower reducibility compared to the other two catalysts. As shown in Table 2, the onset temperatures for reduction for all the catalysts showed slight differences; with VMgO(1) exhibiting the lowest value, while VMgO(2) showed the highest value. Over the three catalysts, vanadium was predominantly reduced from V5+ to V4+, as may be inferred from the oxidation states of vanadium after reduction (Table 2); a minor further reduction of V4+ species may also be proposed [9]. Furthermore, our XRD investigations on the reduced catalysts after the TPR experiments suggest the formation of Mg2VO4, where the vanadium oxidation state is 4+. In support of this, it was shown that under reductive conditions magnesium orthovanadate was converted to MgO and Mg2VO4 [36]. 3.1.6 NH3-temperature-programmed desorption The NH3-TPD data (Table 3 ) reveal that the catalysts show a noticeably different surface acidity; VMgO(2) shows the lowest total surface acidity, while VMgO(1) has the highest acidity. Each of the three catalysts showed three types of acidic sites, viz., weak, medium, and strong acidic sites, which were denoted alpha, beta, and gamma, respectively. The weak acidic sites, which were associated to the desorption of ammonia at 150°C, are likely to be due to the physisorbed ammonia. The medium acidic sites were corresponding to desorption of ammonia at around 420°C, while the strong sites were due to ammonia desorption in the range of 640–670°C. Over all the catalysts, the medium acidic sites seem to be the major source of acidity, as they are obviously greater than the weak and strong acidic sites. It can be concluded from the above that the different approaches in the synthesis produced catalysts with different surface acidity, and that surface acidity was affected by both the precursor used to obtain MgO and the precursor's treatment. 3.2 Catalytic testing The synthesized catalysts were tested over the temperature range of 350–550°C with an interval of 50̊. At each temperature, the catalytic test lasted for 24h and data was obtained at steady state. All the data were obtained in duplicate and carbon balances were in the range of 98–101%. The catalysts produced mainly octenes, C8 aromatics, and carbon oxides. Small amounts of cracking products, octadienes, and traces of oxygenates were also produced. 3.2.1 Activity and products evolution As shown in Fig. 6 , the activation of n-octane starts at 350°C (conversion of 2–3%). Generally, the catalysts VMgO(1) and VMgO(2) (obtained by treating the support's precursor under vacuum) showed a better activity than VMgO(3); the only exception, was at 550°C for the catalyst VMgO(1). The relatively better activity of VMgO(1) at low temperatures (400 and to some extent 450°C) may be attributed to its relatively low onset temperature of reduction (Table 2). As shown in Fig. 7a, selectivity for octenes was higher over VMgO(1), and almost comparable over the other two catalysts; especially in the temperature range 450–550°C. The production of the C8 aromatics, Fig. 7b, started at 400°C; they were not observed at 350°C, where only octenes, carbon oxides, and cracking products were detected. At 400 and 450°C, selectivity for C8 aromatics was higher over VMgO(1), while at 500 and 550°C it was obviously higher over VMgO(2). Over the catalysts VMgO(1) and VMgO(3), the selectivity for COx exhibited a decrease in the temperature range of 350–450°C, and then an increase at the temperatures 500 and 550°C (Fig. 8a). This indeed is opposite to the trend that was shown by C8 aromatics over these two catalysts, indicating a contribution from the secondary combustion of the formed C8 aromatics to the COx selectivity. This is in good agreement with the surface acidity of these two catalysts (Table 3), as they show a relatively higher surface acidity. On such surfaces, the formed aromatics are likely to be held for a longer time on the catalyst surface, thereby giving more chance for combustion of these products to produce COx. In support of this (as shown in Figs. 7b and 8a), the selectivity trends for C8 aromatics and COx over VMgO(2), a catalyst with a relatively low surface acidity (Table 3), do not show an indication of a contribution from the secondary combustion of the formed aromatics. As a characteristic feature of the VMgO system [5,8,9], selectivity to cracking products (C1–C7 alkanes and alkenes) was minimal (1.7–3.1%) in the temperature range 350–500°C (Fig. 8b). However, a steep increase was shown thereafter, i.e. at 550°C; probably because of the contribution from gas phase reactions. 3.2.2 Selectivity at isoconversion At comparable conversions over the three catalysts (≈19%), selectivity for the main products was different (Fig. 9 ). In alkane activation, the breaking of the CH bond is believed to be the rate-determining step, while the way by which the formed surface alkyl or the adsorbed product reacts is the selectivity-determining step [4,37]. In vanadia-based catalysts, selectivity is believed to be affected by the acid–base character of the catalyst's surface [1,4,8], the reducibility of the catalyst (the less reducible the more selective [3,4], and the sizes of the vanadate domains [21,38]. Selectivity to the C8 aromatics and COx over the three catalysts is in good agreement with their surface acidity; VMgO(2), with the lowest acidity, exhibited the highest selectivity to C8 aromatics and the lowest to COx. This is presumably because low acidity will enhance the relatively quick desorption of the formed aromatics (basic), thereby minimizing the chance for the secondary combustion of the formed aromatics to produce COx. This inverse relation between catalyst acidity and selectivity for C8 aromatics and COx is also applicable to the catalysts VMgO(1) and VMgO(3). Octenes selectivity over the three catalysts exhibited an opposite trend to that shown by C8 aromatics. This, along with the fact that C8 aromatics started to form at 400°C (Section 3.2.1), indicates that octenes are precursors to C8 aromatics, and that the latter were probably produced from n-octane via the sequential reaction: n-octane→octenes→octadienes/octatrienes→C8 aromatics However, the small amounts of octadienes and octatrienes imply that these compounds are rapidly removed from the system during the formation of the C8 aromatics, and these reactions are presumably driven by the stability of the aromatics. As shown in Section 3.2.1, selectivity for cracking products (C1–C7 alkanes and alkenes) was minimal. Notable is that the overall ODH selectivity over VMgO(2) was higher than that of the other two catalysts, which is consistent with its low acidity as well as its relatively low reducibility as may be inferred from the T max in the TPR data (Table 2). This relatively high ODH selectivity over VMgO(2) may also be related to the observation that the manifestation of the crystalline Mg3V2O8 phase was poor in this catalyst (Section 3.1.2.); in support of this, a recent ab initio study on a vanadium–MgO catalyst suggested that for a better oxidative dehydrogenation performance, the formation of Mg3V2O8 should be avoided [39]. More details about the aromatization products at isoconversion are shown in Fig. 10 ; styrene was the dominant C8 aromatic over the three catalysts, followed by ethylbenzene, and then o-xylene as the least formed C8 aromatic. Moreover, and as expected from the catalysts’ surface acidity (Table 3), selectivity for each of styrene, ethylbenzene, and o-xylene was highest over VMgO(2) and lowest over VMgO(1). 3.2.3 Production of 1-octene and styrene 1-Octene (an alpha alkene) and styrene are valuable products that are used in the polymers industry; polystyrene is in fact one of the most important polymers. Hence, especial attention has been given to the production of these two products. As shown in Fig. 11a, the production of 1-octene was higher over the catalysts VMgO(1) and VMgO(2) (vacuum prepared precursors); an exception was at the temperature of 550°C for VMgO(1). For styrene production (Fig. 11b), the yield was higher over VMgO(1) at the temperatures of 400 and 450°C, but was obviously greater over VMgO(2) at high temperatures (500 and 550°C). This, again, emphasizes the apparent positive effect of treating the support precursor under vacuum. 3.2.4 Modes of cyclization and mechanistic inspections The cyclization of n-octane to form a six-member ring could either take place through C1–C6 or C2–C7 closure. The former is believed to lead to the formation of ethylcyclohexane, ethylbenzene or styrene, while the latter will form o-xylene [40–42]. As shown in Fig. 12 , C1–C6 was the favourable mode of cyclization, while the C2–C7 mode of cyclization was far lower (ranging between 9.8 and 15.4%). A slight increase in the C2–C7 mode of cyclization with temperature was observed (Fig. 12); probably because the temperature may provide the energy required to overcome any activation barriers. Moreover, it can be inferred from Fig. 12 that C2–C7 cyclization, which is associated to o-xylene formation, was generally lower over VMgO(2) (a catalyst with a relatively lower acidity). This is supported by a report that there was a parallelism between a catalyst's acidity and xylenes formation [43]. According to the mechanism proposed for alkane activation [2,4,37], the transformation of n-octane can be initiated by hydrogen abstraction (slow step) to form an octyl specie. A second elimination of hydrogen from an adjacent carbon atom (fast step) will lead to the formation of an octene. In alkane activation, the way in which the formed alkyl specie reacts is crucial in determining the selectivity to a certain class of products, e.g. oxygenates, cracking, or dehydrogenation products [4,44]. The VMgO system is well known for preferentially taking the dehydrogenation route, rather than cracking and oxygenates formation routes [4,45]. Therefore, the formed octenes may either desorb from the catalyst's surface or be dehydrogenated in subsequent steps that eventually lead to the cyclization and aromatics formation. As mentioned above, this cyclization is believed to proceed via a mechanism that involves the formation of a six-membered carbon ring through 1–6 (Fig. 13 , I and II) or 2–7 (Fig. 13, III) ring closure [40–42]: If the above two modes of cyclization are equally probable, the combined amount of ethylbenzene and styrene would be as twice that of o-xylene. The results of the catalytic testing, however, showed that the amounts of o-xylene were far lower than what can be predicted by the equal probability of the reaction pathways shown in Fig. 13. This clearly indicates that the 1–6 ring closure that leads to the formation of ethylbenzene and styrene was the preferred mode of cyclization during the n-octane activation. The low amounts of benzene and toluene formed (combined selectivity of 1–2.5%) indicate that neither significant cracking of n-octane (octenes) nor hydrogenolysis of the formed C8 aromatics has occurred, as it was reported that these two products may result from the hydrogenolysis of the formed C8 aromatics [46,47]. This is consistent with the fact that the VMgO system is not known for cracking or hydrogen activation. Also, an interesting feature in the aromatization of n-octane was that o-xylene was overwhelmingly the dominant isomer among xylenes. For the formation of m- and p-xylenes from an alkane of eight carbon atoms, the following ring closures shown in Fig. 14 were suggested [41,48]: It can be noted from the above that for m- and p-xylenes to be formed, an isomerization of n-octane must first take place. Since the VMgO system is not known for this kind of reaction, it is justifiable that these two xylene isomers are unlikely to form, and that o-xylene is notably the dominant isomer. 4 Conclusions Changing the MgO precursor and precursor treatment induced changes on the textural as well as on the chemical properties of the resultant VMgO catalysts, viz., crystallite sizes, vanadium dispersion, reducibility, and catalysts’ surface acidity. As a consequence, the catalytic performance was also different. Over all the catalysts, magnesium oxide and magnesium orthovanadate were the only crystalline phases detected. The manifestation of the orthovanadate phase on these catalysts, however, was different, and was differently affected by the MgO precursor. Moreover, a good dehydrogenation performance was associated with a poor manifestation of the orthovanadate phase. Treating the support precursor under vacuum produced catalysts with rough surfaces and relatively better catalytic performance. Over the three catalysts, the merits of the VMgO system were maintained, in that only small amounts of cracking products and oxygenates were formed. Differences in selectivity for different products were better explained by the acidity of the catalysts’ surfaces. This surface acidity was found to be influenced by both the precursor used to produce MgO and the precursor's treatment. Moreover, an inverse relation between selectivity and vanadium reducibility was also observed. Cyclization took place predominantly via the C1–C6 mode, and ethylbenzene and styrene were the dominant C8 aromatics. Moreover, o-xylene was the dominant xylene isomer. To sum up, the properties and the catalytic performance of the VMgO system were influenced by the preparation history of the support (MgO). coredata.dc:description: VMgO catalysts with a V2O5 loading of 15% were prepared by the wet impregnation method. Catalysts synthesis was carried out by employing different MgO precursors (MgC2O4 and Mg(OH)2) and different precursors treatments (under vacuum and under static air). The synthesized catalysts were characterized by ICP-OES, BET, powder XRD, SEM, EDX, 51V NMR, H2-TPR, and NH3-TPD. The catalysts were tested for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-octane using a continuous flow fixed bed reactor at GHSV of 8000h−1 and n-octane/O2 molar ratio of 0.8. Changing the above synthesis parameters led to the formation of catalysts with different morphologies, textural properties, and acidity. As a consequence, the results of the catalytic testing were also different, and treating the MgO precursors under vacuum induced a general positive effect on the catalytic performance. The aromatization of n-octane was predominantly via C1–C6 bonding.
